review.title: A Time and Space Efficient Junction Tree Architecture
review.abstract:
In this paper we introduce the fast product format, the use of which allows fast computation of a product of many potentials (an operation in the junction tree algorithm (see Shafer, Shenoy: "Probability Propagation")). When combined with the use of the inclusion exclusion format (see Smith, Gogate: "The Inclusion-Exculsion Rule and its Application to the Junction Tree Algorithm") which allows for fast computation of many marginals of a potential, the junction tree algorithm can be made significantly faster in many cases. The exclusion of the exclusion format can only be implemented by using the exclusion format which is used by the exclusion format as well.





The exclusion format
As a result, we consider it convenient to introduce it to any user (except in cases where it is difficult or expensive). For example: the exclusion formats of any part of a node (or node in particular) can be easily made for use in the application. It is a good idea to define the exclusion format of a node in some form. A block diagram, for example, could also be represented using the exclusion format.

The exclusion format
An exclusion format is a format that is used by a user with different characteristics (e.g., the height, etc.) when the user has specified it. However, it has to be implemented as a feature of a specific node. In addition to using the exclusion format, it can also be used to represent the exclusion format of a node in particular or in certain circumstances.
In the case of an exclusion format, it can also be implemented by using the exclusion format which is used by the exclusion format which is used by the exclusion format as well. For example, the exclusion format can be used as a feature of a particular node in particular or in certain circumstances. However, it has to be implemented as a feature of a specific node. In addition to using the exclusion format, it can also be used to represent the exclusion format of a node in particular or in certain circumstances. In addition to using the exclusion format, it can also be used to represent the exclusion format of a node in particular or in certain circumstances. In addition to using the exclusion format, it can also be used to represent the exclusion format of a node in particular or in certain circumstances. The exclusion format can also be used to represent the exclusion format of a node in particular or in certain circumstances.

upsweep and downsweep take a time of O ( ∑
Γ∈J deg(Γ)2 |Γ|
)
. The use
of Inclusion Exclusion Format (IEF) (Smith, Gogate: “The InclusionExculsion Rule and its Application to the Junction Tree Algorithm”) allows the downsweep (which involves calculating possibly a large number of marginals of a potential at each internal vertex of J ) to be done in a time of O ( ∑
Γ∈J |Γ|2 |Γ|
)
, which, in many cases, is a very large saving
in complexity. Upsweep (which involves taking the product of possibly a large number of potentials at each internal vertex of J ), however, still takes a time of O ( ∑
Γ∈J deg(Γ)2 |Γ|
)
(so the use of IEF alone does not
reduce the time complexity of the full batch junction tree algorithm). In this paper we introduce the Fast Product Format (FPF) which allows the upsweep, also, to be done in a time of O ( ∑
Γ∈J |Γ|2 |Γ|
)
(hence, by using
both IEF and FPF we can do the full batch junction tree algorithm in a time of O ( ∑
Γ∈J |Γ|2 |Γ|
)
).
Preliminaries: Given a set X we define P(X) to be the power set of X (that is, the set of subsets of X) and define |X | to be the cardinality of X (that is, the number of elements in X). A collection is a set that may contain duplicate elements (we use the subset symbol, S ⊆ X , to denote that every element in the collection S is also contained in the set X). This paper assumes we have a alebian group G who’s identity is denoted 1. Given an element a ∈ G we define a−1 to be the inverse element of a. Given elements a, b ∈ G we define ab to be the product of a and b in G. Given a finite collection S ⊆ G we define ∏
a∈S a to be the product of all elements of S (i.e. if S = {ai : i ∈ Nk}, we have ∏
a∈S a := a1a2a3...ak). Given an element a ∈ G we define a 0 := 1.
For i ∈ N \ {0} we inductively define ai (resp. a−i) to be equal to aai−1 (resp. a−1a−i+1). We assume that the group product operation and the inverse operation both take a time of O(1).
Definition 1. A potential on a set X is a function from P(X) to G. Given a set X, the set of potentials on X is denoted T (X).
Note that a potential on a set X represents a function from the set of all binary valued labelings of X into G.
Definition 2. Given a set X and a collection of potentials S ⊆ T (X), we define the product, ∏
Ψ∈S Ψ as the potential Ψ̃ ∈ T (X) that satisfies, for every Y ∈ P(X):
Ψ̃(Y ) := ∏
Ψ∈S
Ψ(Y ) (1)
Definition 3. Given a set X, a subset Y ∈ P(X) and a potential Ψ ∈ T (Y ), the extension, [Ψ, X ], of Ψ to X is the potential in T (X) that satisfies, for every Z ∈ P(X):
[Ψ, X ](Z) = Ψ(Z ∩ Y ) (2)
The problem that this paper solves is as follows: We have a set X , a collection of subsets {Xi : i ∈ Nk} where each Xi is in P(X), and a collection of potentials {Ψi : i ∈ Nk} where each Ψi is in T (Xi). We wish to compute the product ∏k
i=0[Ψi, X ]. The direct computation of this product would take a time of O(k2|X|). In this paper we introduce the fast product format of a potential, the use of which allows us to compute the product in a time of O ( |X |2|X| + ∑k
i=0 |Xi|2 |Xi|
)
.
Hence, in the cases that k is much larger than |X | and the sets Xi are much smaller than X , using the fast product format greatly decreases the time complexity. The use of fast product format requires only linear space complexity.
Definition 4. Given a number i ∈ N and an element x ∈ G, we define E (i, x) to be equal to x if i is even and x−1 otherwise.
Definition 5. Given a set X and a potential Ψ ∈ T (X), the fast product format (FPF), Ψ′, of Ψ is the potential in T (X) that satisfies, for every Y ∈ P(X):
Ψ′(Y ) = ∏
Z∈P(Y )

We now show how an FPF can be recursively computed:
Theorem 6. Suppose we have a set X and a potential Ψ ∈ T (X). Suppose we have some element v ∈ X. Let [Ψ−] be the potential in T (X \ {v}) that satisfies, for all Y ∈ P(X \ {v}), [Ψ−](Y ) := Ψ(Y ) and let [Ψ+] be the potential in T (X \ {v}) that satisfies, for all Y ∈ P(X \ {v}), [Ψ+](Y ) := Ψ(Y ∪ {v}). Then for all Y ∈ P(X \ {v}) we have:
1. Ψ′(Y ) = [Ψ−] ′ (Y )

We now show how to derive the FPF of an extension (from the FPF of the original potential) and demonstrate its sparsity:
Lemma 9. Given a set X, a subset Y ∈ P(X) and a potential Ψ ∈ T (Y ), the FPF of the potential [Ψ, X ] satisfies, for every Z ∈ P(X):
1. If Z ⊆ Y , [Ψ, X ] ′ (Z) = Ψ′(Z)
2. If Z * Y , [Ψ, X ]′(Z) = 1

By combining lemmas 9 and 10 we obtain the following theorem, which shows how to rapidly compute the product of extensions when working in FPF:
Theorem 11. Suppose we have a set X, a collection of subsets {Xi : i ∈ Nk} where each Xi is in P(X), and a collection of potentials {Ψi : i ∈ Nk} where each Ψi is in T (Xi). Then given any Y ∈ P(X):

By plugging equation 60 and 62 into equation 59 we obtain the result.
We now give the time complexities of two operations involving fast product formats (both algorithms rely on the input potentials being stored in full balanced binary trees. The output potentials are stored in the same structure. This structure also allows for fast computation of a marginal):
Algorithm 12. Given a set X and a potential Ψ ∈ T (X), if we have an input of Ψ, we can compute Ψ′ in a time of O ( |X |2|X| )
Proof. The algorithm, given in the full version of the paper, rests on theorem 6.
Algorithm 13. Given a set X, a collection of subsets {Xi : i ∈ Nk} where each Xi is in P(X), and a collection of potentials {Ψi : i ∈ Nk} where each Ψi is in T (Xi), if we have an input of {Ψ ′ i : i ∈ Nk} we can compute [ ∏k i=0[Ψi, X ] ]′ in a time of O ( 2|X| + ∑k
i=0 2 |Xi|
)
.
Proof. The algorithm, given in the full version of the paper, rests on theorem 11.
We now turn to the problem given at the start of the paper. We first use algo-
rithm 12 to convert each Ψi to Ψi ′, which takes a total time ofO
(
∑k
i=0 |Xi|2 |Xi|
)
.
We next use algorithm 13 to compute [ ∏k i=0[Ψi, X ] ]′ , which takes a time of O ( 2|X| + ∑k
i=0 2 |Xi|
)
. By theorem 8 we can then use algorithm 12 to convert [
∏k i=0[Ψi, X ] ]′ to ∏k i=0[Ψi, X ], which takes a time of O ( |X |2|X| ) . This implies
the total time complexity of O ( |X |2|X| + ∑k
i=0 |Xi|2 |Xi|
)
.

A collection is a set that may contain duplicate elements (we use the subset symbol, S ⊆ X , to denote that every element in the collection S is also contained in the set X). This paper assumes we have a alebian group G who’s identity is denoted 1. Given an element a ∈ G we define a to be the inverse element of a.
